body:
### Problem

When using `vim.fn.termopen`, if I set the `on_stdout` and `on_stderr` functions, for the `termopen` and then run something producing lot of changing output in the term, like `btop`, then the `nvim` process will begin to accumulate memory that will not be freed up even after the terminal is closed.

### Steps to reproduce

```
nvim --clean
:lua vim.fn.termopen(vim.o.shell, {cdw = vim.fn.getcwd(),on_stdout = function(chan, data, _) end, on_stderr = function(chan, data, _) end, })
```

In another terminal, check out the nvim process memory consumption: `ps -o rss= <pid>`, where `pid` is the neovim process id.

You can check the memory consumption for a minute. You will notice the same memory footprint. 

Then, in the nvim terminal, open `btop`. Select a process from the list of processes. Now let the `nvim` terminal untouched. 

In the other terminal, check again the memory consumption of the `nvim` process every 30 seconds or so. You will notice that it keeps growing without stopping.

*NOTE*

If I run the termopen without the `on_stdout` and `on_stderr` functions, like this:
```
:lua vim.fn.termopen(vim.o.shell, {cdw = vim.fn.getcwd()})
```
then there is no memory leak. The memory consumption will remain the same after opening `btop` after several hours.


### Expected behavior

While the `btop` is opened in the terminal process, the memory consumption of the `nvim` process should remain unchanged.

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

0.9.4 latest stable

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

N/A since the `termopen` is neovim specific

### Operating system/version

Arch linux 6.4.1-zen2-1-zen

### Terminal name/version

XTerm(383)

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

App image from the latest releases
title: Terminal memory leak
